Norwegian Refugee Council

organisation.narrative: Norwegian Refugee Council

mailing-address.narrative: Prinsensgate 2, 0152 Oslo, Norway

reporting-org.narrative: Norwegian Refugee Council

title.narrative: Protecting vulnerable communities in Somalia from the spread and impact of the COVID-19 virus through the BRCiS consortium (Closed)

description.narrative: Following the emergence and declaration of COVID-19 pandemic, BRCIS re-programmed around 5,5M GBP worth of activities for all BRCiS locations to scale up sensitization, health and nutrition outreach, WASH activities and livelihoods through the use of cash. The activities were anchored within a wider BRCiS collective COVID-19 preparedness and response plan.

participating-org.narrative: Norwegian Refugee Council
UK - Department for International Development (DFID)

mailing-address.narrative: Prinsensgate 2, 0152 Oslo, Norway

reporting-org.narrative: Norwegian Refugee Council

title.narrative: Supporting preparedness, mitigation and response to the primary and secondary impacts of COVID-19 on IDP and vulnerable populations in Yemen (Closed)

description.narrative: Given the context of COVID-19, combined with the already dire humanitarian needs in Yemen, our approach aims to prevent, mitigate and respond to COVID-19: in the immediate/short-term by providing life-saving assistance through targeted and coordinated activities in WASH, protection, and cash to IDP and vulnerable populations. The programme will provide an integrated, package across two governorates; Hodeidah and Taizz.

participating-org.narrative: DFID
Norwegian Refugee Council

mailing-address.narrative: Prinsensgate 2, 0152 Oslo, Norway

reporting-org.narrative: The Leprosy Mission Nepal

title.narrative: Leveraging leprosy infrastructure to strengthen the COVID19 response

description.narrative: The Project will increase the preparedness of Anandaban Hospital to deliver critical COVID-19 care to patients experiencing COVID-19 complications including vulnerable individuals including people affected by leprosy and disabilities and to protect the most vulnerable and health workers from infection. The project will do this by training all staff in COVID-19 response including testing, treating, and managing cases; opening an isolation ward aimed to treat critical patients using ventilators and respirators; providing counselling sessions for both staff and patients struggling with their experience of COVID-19; sharing awareness-raising messages about how to keep safe during the pandemic; and by distributing food and sanitation packages amongst households in the local community.

participating-org.narrative: The Leprosy Mission England and Wales

title.narrative: Solomon Islands Tourism Recovery Programme

description.narrative: To assist Solomon Islands Government to develop a sustainable niche tourism industry in Western Province, including supporting an industry response to and recovery from the impacts of COVID-19. This activity is currently in design, and will likely focus on interventions to support tourism marketing, product development, sectoral coordination and investment, and preparing the industry for post COVID-19 tourism considerations.

title.narrative: MF1-01 Inclusive Education in Papua New Guinea

description.narrative: Leveraging gains from a previous NZ Aid Programme funded activity (PF 3-413 Papua New Guinea - Education and Rehabilitation for children with disabilities) cbm (Christian Blind Mission NZ) will provide inclusive education and health services for people with disabilities in PNG, supporting over 30,000 direct beneficiaries. The activity will include COVID-19 awareness raising and information, as well as equal access to health services for the most vulnerable groups in remote areas in PNG.

title.narrative: MF1-04 Planem Gud Famili Blong Yumi sexual and reproductive health and rights Phase Two in Vanuatu

description.narrative: Family Planning NZ (FPNZ) will implement phase two of the activity Planem Gud Famili Blong Yumi sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) in Vanuatu. Phase two will be funded through Manaaki and will build on the success of the Partnerships for International Development (PFID) activity PF10-588 Planem Gud Famili Blong Yumi SRHR in Vanuatu. FPNZ is also supporting their in-country partner, Vanuatu Family Health Association (VFHA), to assist the Vanuatu MoH in its COVID-19 programme.

reporting-org.narrative: New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade

title.narrative: Occupied Palestinian Territories :Explosive Ordnance Risk Education

description.narrative: The Activity will support efforts to reduce the risk of harm from explosive hazards in the West Bank of the Occupied Palestinian Territories through (1) enabling the Palestinian Mine Action Center to deliver Explosive Ordnance risk education (EORE) in the West Bank, (2) training trainers to continue providing EORE, and (3) institutional strengthening of the PMAC. WHO messaging on hand washing and social distancing will be incorporated to minimise risk of spreading COVID during or after training.

title.narrative: Covid-19 - 2020 Tonga Immediate Health Systems Preparedness Activity

description.narrative: Support to Tonga for preparedness and response to a potential Covid-19 outbreak in the region. Initial fund from Cabinet Paper approved 16/03/2020. Tonga requested support for its strategic preparedness and response plan for COVID-19, costed at a total NZ$3.2 million. This includes medical equipment and supplies, the renovation of a community health centre, PPE, transport and lab supplies. New Zealand will provide a NZD1 million untagged grant.

description.narrative: The United Nations (UN) COVID-19 Response and Recovery Multi-Partner Trust Fund (COVID-19 MPTF) is a UN inter-agency finance mechanism launched by the UN Secretary-General to support low and middle income programme countries in overcoming the health and development crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Fund’s assistance targets those most vulnerable to economic hardship and social disruption. A contribution will be ear-marked for sub-Sahara Africa.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Improve Cook Islands' Health Capability: PCR laboratory and ICU

description.narrative:
This Activity is strengthening the Cook Islands' laboratory and critical care capability, and vaccine cold storage capacity, to support readiness for a COVID-19/other infectious disease outbreak, quarantine-free travel and vaccine rollout. It is establishing:
  • local 'gold standard' polymerase chain reaction testing capability (lab alterations, machine, equipment, consumables, training); 
  • improved critical care  (equipment, training); and
  • sufficient vaccine cold storage capacity.

title.narrative: Covid-19 - Suppporting the World Bank COVID project that will establish a Public Health Laboratory

description.narrative: This activity provides funding towards the World Bank COVID-19 Emergency Response Project, designed in partnership with the Ministrty of Health in Samoa. Specifically, New Zealand will fund sub-component 2.2: Establishment of a Public Health Laboratory for human and animal health. This sub-component falls under Component 2: Systems Strengthening for Pandemic Preparedness and Response; in turn it is one of the three project components supporting Samoa's response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Maori/Pacific Tourism Partnership - Aho Rua / Va'a tele

description.narrative: A long-term Maori / Pacific tourism partnership, led by New Zealand Maori Tourism. Maori tourism operators are world class in indigenous business operations, and developing visitor experiences based on cultural interpretation and interactions. Mutually beneficial reciprocal Maori/Pacific B2B relationships are formed, indigenous business expertise is shared. Pacific destination and product differentiation improves post-COVID returns, moving Pacific visitor experiences up the value chain.

title.narrative: Repatriation Services for Stranded Scholars

description.narrative: Centralising the repatriation of scholars stranded in NZ as a result of COVID 19-related border closures, to cover scholars who have completed their qualifications but are unable to repatriate within the standard 14 days. Such scholars will be placed in a pool for the service provider to manage. Management will consist of scholar needs analysis (dependents, etc), identifying commercial and (particularly) non-commercial repatriation options, travel management and reporting to MFAT.

title.narrative: COVID-19 and Flood Response in Timor Leste (2021): UNICEF

description.narrative: Support for provision of humanitarian relief in Timor-Leste following catastrophic 4 April flooding, and in response to community transmission of Covid-19. Activities include distribution of humanitarian supplies to flood-affected families, provision of water and sanitation facilities in evacuation shelters, nutrition and education support for mothers and children, and social protection (including child protection and people with disabilities).

title.narrative: COVID-19 Ancillary costs for 1.668m COVAX donation

description.narrative: NZ has agreed to donate 834,000 courses (1,668 million doses) of the AstraZeneca vaccine - purchased through the COVAX Facility for New Zealand’s domestic needs - back to the COVAX AMC. These doses will be earmarked for the wider Pacific (Fiji, Solomon Islands, Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu and Kiribati).Vaccine costs paid for by Vote Health, but ancillary costs such as No Fault Compensation levy (US$0.10 per dose), Safe Injection Equipment and freight are to be covered by MFAT.

title.narrative: Covid-19 NZ contribution to UNICEF regional plan for vaccine rollout

description.narrative: Funding of NZ$2m over three years to supplement current gaps in UNICEF’s planned support for Pacific countries’ Covid-19 vaccine and country readiness. New Zealand’s contribution will be directed to support six Pacific countries – Fiji, Kiribati, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Vanuatu – and will cover activities in both health and communication and demand generation. These gaps are fluid, and may be subject to change based on UNICEF’s assessment of the Covid-19 situation in the Pacific.

title.narrative: Cook Islands COVID-19 Economic Recovery

description.narrative: This Activity provides a $30 million grant to the Cook Islands as budget support to assist economic recovery from COVID-19 and sustain cash reserves while tourism revenue recovers. It is part of a broader package of economic support, which includes an additional $2 million private sector support, and builds on $42 million COVID-19 budget support provided to the Cook Islands since March 2020.

title.narrative: Indonesia: COVID-19 Whole Genome Sequencing Support

description.narrative: This Activity will provide specialist equipment and reagents to the Eijkman Institute's genome centre laboratory to assist with performing whole genome sequencing of SARS-CoV-2, to aid surveillance and information on the circulating SARS-CoV-2 genomes and variants in Indonesia to assist in the pandemic response.
